channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Reporting backlog continues to affect L.A. County COVID-19 case numbers
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,192 new cases of the coronavirus and nine related deaths but said both numbers were artificially low due to a weekend reporting lag.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,192 new cases of the coronavirus and nine related deaths but said both numbers were artificially low due to a weekend reporting lag.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - AUGUST 12, 2020 - -Richard Hernandes, from right to left, his girlfriend Jazmin Domingo, his brothers Seth Patlan, 5, and Joseph Hamassian, heed the, "Masks Up, Surf City," banner campaign to prevent coronavirus on Main Street in Huntington Beach on August 12, 2020. The campaign, a play on the phrase "Surf's Up," includes 100 pennants, a banner at the pier and digital displays citywide, Huntington Beach spokeswoman Catherine Jun said. Fifty pennants were installed downtown on Aug. 6. The remaining signs are in production this week, and 13 pennants and a banner are expected to be installed on the Huntington Beach Pier. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Massive wildfire spawns fire tornadoes in Northern California
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Multiple videos posted to social media showed twister-like formations in the path of the Loyalton fire, which started Friday evening in the Tahoe National Forest.
item.content:encoded: Multiple videos posted to social media showed twister-like formations in the path of the Loyalton fire, which started Friday evening in the Tahoe National Forest.

media:content.media:description: A firefighting helicopter makes an approach to drop water on the Ranch fire in the hills above a cluster of homes along the San Gabriel River near Azusa.

item.title: Moisture from Tropical Storm Fausto fuels Northern California storms
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: Widespread red flag warnings are in effect across Northern California because of dry lightning strikes
item.content:encoded: Widespread red flag warnings are in effect across Northern California because of dry lightning strikes

media:content.media:description: Moisture plume from Tropical Storm Fausto streaming toward Northern California is seen in a satellite image from noon Sunday.

item.title: Long Beach mayor among keynote speakers at upcoming Democratic National Convention
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: Long Beach Mayor Robert Garcia is among 17 current and former Democratic officials set to deliver the DNC keynote address on Tuesday.
item.content:encoded: Long Beach Mayor Robert Garcia is among 17 current and former Democratic officials set to deliver the DNC keynote address on Tuesday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 13, 2020. Portrait of Long Beach Mayor Robert Garcia at Long Beach City Hall on Friday, Aug. 14, 2020. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Los Angeles County church appears ready to defy court order and hold indoor services
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: Late Saturday, an appellate court set aside a lower court order to allow indoor services at Grace Community Church. But services are set to take place as usual.
item.content:encoded: Late Saturday, an appellate court set aside a lower court order to allow indoor services at Grace Community Church. But services are set to take place as usual.

item.title: Federal judge orders COVID-19 testing at Bakersfield immigration detention facility
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Judge orders COVID-19 testing at Bakersfield immigration detention center where a spreading outbreak was met with 'deliberate indifference' for weeks.
item.content:encoded: Judge orders COVID-19 testing at Bakersfield immigration detention center where a spreading outbreak was met with 'deliberate indifference' for weeks.

media:content.media:description: Hunger strikers at Mesa Verde ICE Processing Center in Bakersfield captured by drone during a sit-in protest on April 10.
media:content.media:credit: Courtesy of the California Committee for Immigrant Liberation

item.title: Column One: Nearly half a century ago, activists 'invaded' this California island by claiming it for Mexico
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: In 1972, the mission of the Brown Berets was to occupy Catalina Island — land they believed belonged to Mexico. Nearly 48 years later, Chicano leader David Sanchez revisits the island and the legacy of the Berets' three-week occupation.
item.content:encoded: In 1972, the mission of the Brown Berets was to occupy Catalina Island — land they believed belonged to Mexico. Nearly 48 years later, Chicano leader David Sanchez revisits the island and the legacy of the Berets' three-week occupation.

media:content.media:description: CATALINA ISLAND, CA - AUGUST 07: Activist David Sanchez, of Huntington Park, who led the Brown Berets during the occupational protest in Catalina Island in 1972 as part of the Chicano Moratorium, revisit the point where he once protested in Avalon Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Catalina Island. The group of 26 planted a large Mexican flag on the point, referred to as Burrito Point by some locals, above the Chimes Tower and claimed the island in the name of Mexico. The Brown Berets are a pro-Chicano organization that emerged during the Chicano Movement in the late1960s to address the issues of educational reform, farm workers' rights, police brutality, anti-war activities and other problems confronting the Chicano community and was founded by Sanchez. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus complicates California's worst power shortage in two decades
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Jack Dolan
item.description: People staying home with air conditioners blasting, plus a dearth of power from other states results in the worst statewide energy shortage in nearly 20 years
item.content:encoded: People staying home with air conditioners blasting, plus a dearth of power from other states results in the worst statewide energy shortage in nearly 20 years

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - AUG. 15, 2020.: Beachgoers create a forest of umbrellas as thousands seek refuge in Santa Monica with temperatures reaching triple digits and beyond in inland valleys and deserts on Saturday, Aug. 15, 2020. A heatwave caused by a high pressure system over Southern California is expected to last through next week. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Agent of colonialism' or a 'saint for our times'? Junipero Serra's legacy divides Latinos
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Latinos have served as the most vocal detractors and defenders of Junípero Serra over the last few months in a fierce debate about the saint's legacy.
item.content:encoded: Latinos have served as the most vocal detractors and defenders of Junípero Serra over the last few months in a fierce debate about the saint's legacy.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - AUGUST 01: Veronica Valadez, 46, stands for a portrait where a statue of Fr. Juniper Serra once stood in front of Ventura city hall on Saturday, Aug. 1, 2020 in Ventura, CA. Valadez is one of several Latino detractors of Fr. Junipero Serra and believes the saint's work to convert local indigenous groups and build the California Mission system was oppressive, destructive of local cultures and led to many deaths of indigenous peoples. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Rare lightning storms threaten California after 'wild night' sparks multiple Bay Area fires
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: There's an elevated risk of fire danger across wide swaths of California because of the risk of lightning.
item.content:encoded: There's an elevated risk of fire danger across wide swaths of California because of the risk of lightning.

media:content.media:description: Lightning is seen in the San Francisco Bay Area Sunday.

item.title: Los Angeles County reports more than 2,100 new coronavirus cases and 35 more related deaths
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: The new numbers brought the county's totals to 220,762 positive cases of COVID-19 and 5,245 deaths. Saturday's death total was the lowest of any day this week.
item.content:encoded: The new numbers brought the county's totals to 220,762 positive cases of COVID-19 and 5,245 deaths. Saturday's death total was the lowest of any day this week.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08: EMT Hannah Mikus, right, demonstrates how to self administer the test to drivers during Coronavirus Covid-19 testing in LA County at the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in South Los Angeles on July 8, 2020 as California records its highest single-day coronavirus death toll with 149 fatalities reported. The Charles R. Drew University site has tested a large number of people from racial and ethnic minority groups that are at higher risk for poor outcomes and complications from COVID-19. Drew University on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Lake and Ranch 2 fires burn thousands of acres as region is gripped in epic heat wave
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: The Lake fire near Lake Hughes and the Ranch 2 fire above Azusa have forced widespread evacuations and worsened air quality during an epic heat wave.
item.content:encoded: The Lake fire near Lake Hughes and the Ranch 2 fire above Azusa have forced widespread evacuations and worsened air quality during an epic heat wave.

item.title: More rolling blackouts ordered in California amid power shortages and searing heat
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller, Paul Duginski, Tony Barboza, Jack Dolan, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: The broiling conditions that began Friday in California may rival the deadly seven-day heat event of July 2006.
item.content:encoded: The broiling conditions that began Friday in California may rival the deadly seven-day heat event of July 2006.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - AUG. 15, 2020.: Beachgoers create a forest of umbrellas as thousands seek refuge in Santa Monica with temperatures reaching triple digits and beyond in inland valleys and deserts on Saturday, Aug. 15, 2020. A heatwave caused by a high pressure system over Southern California is expected to last through next week. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: State's freeze of COVID-19 watchlist magnifies breakdown in communication to counties
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The state's coronavirus watch list, which guides the state's decision to allow counties to open certain sectors, including schools and in-person service at places of worship, was frozen last week after state officials announced that a backlog with test result data had led to an inaccurate count of cases.
item.content:encoded: The state's coronavirus watch list, which guides the state's decision to allow counties to open certain sectors, including schools and in-person service at places of worship, was frozen last week after state officials announced that a backlog with test result data had led to an inaccurate count of cases.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - AUGUST 12, 2020 - - A couple walk past a sign that reads, "Please Wear Mask," in front of Dash of Sass clothing store along Main Street during a "Masks Up, Surf City," banner campaign to prevent coronavirus in the city of Huntington Beach on August 12, 2020. Customers are not allowed into the store unless they are wearing a mask. The campaign, a play on the phrase "Surf's Up," includes 100 pennants, a banner at the pier and digital displays citywide, Huntington Beach spokeswoman Catherine Jun said. Fifty pennants were installed downtown on Aug. 6. The remaining signs are in production this week, and 13 pennants and a banner are expected to be installed on the Huntington Beach Pier. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Lopez: A pandemic road trip isn't for cowards. Things to know before you go
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: The rest stop was another 60 miles up the road, which seemed as far off as a reliable vaccine, but I made it in the nick of time.
item.content:encoded: The rest stop was another 60 miles up the road, which seemed as far off as a reliable vaccine, but I made it in the nick of time.

media:content.media:description: While Napa County is only planted to 8% vineyards, some places look like an undulating sea of vine rows.

item.title: Long Beach mayor loses mother, stepfather to COVID weeks apart. He wants people to learn from it
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: "The days go pretty late" for Mayor Robert Garcia, who must guide Long Beach through a global health crisis while mourning two family members.
item.content:encoded: "The days go pretty late" for Mayor Robert Garcia, who must guide Long Beach through a global health crisis while mourning two family members.

media:content.media:description: Long Beach mayor Robert Garcia (right) holds his mother's hand during her wedding as Greg O'Donnell's mother holds his. Gaby and Greg O'Donnell both died due to complications from COVID-19.

item.title: Column: I wasn't a fan of Kamala Harris. It took President Trump to change my mind
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: Many Black progressives weren't fans of Kamala Harris. But President Trump's racist attacks have proved exactly why supporting her is necessary.
item.content:encoded: Many Black progressives weren't fans of Kamala Harris. But President Trump's racist attacks have proved exactly why supporting her is necessary.

media:content.media:description: Democratic presidential candidate former Vice President Joe Biden listens as his running mate Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif., speaks during a campaign event at Alexis Dupont High School in Wilmington, Del., Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020. (AP Photo/Carolyn Kaster)

item.title: A beloved L.A. bakery's fight to survive the coronavirus reminds us to help out places we'd miss
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: Diamond Bakery on L.A.'s Fairfax Ave. has survived a lot over 74 years. Loyal customers and a GoFundMe campaign hope to carry it through the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Diamond Bakery on L.A.'s Fairfax Ave. has survived a lot over 74 years. Loyal customers and a GoFundMe campaign hope to carry it through the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 12: Alexes (cq) Luna helps a customer at Diamond Bakery on Fairfax Avenue. The store has been around since 1946 but its sales have plummeted because of the pandemic. A GoFundMe campaign was started to help pay the bills and to keep from having to lay off employees. Photographed at Diamond Bakery on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Low-wage workers face retaliation for demanding COVID-19 safety measures at work
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Some of the state's largest coronavirus outbreaks have occurred in workplaces, but fear of retaliation is preventing employees from voicing safety concerns, workers and labor organizers say.
item.content:encoded: Some of the state's largest coronavirus outbreaks have occurred in workplaces, but fear of retaliation is preventing employees from voicing safety concerns, workers and labor organizers say.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 30: Lizett Aguilar poses for a portrait outside of her home in East Los Angeles on Thursday, July 30, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Aguilar said that after she helped lead strikes at a Domino's in Boyle Heights over unsafe working conditions, her supervisor retaliated against her by making her job more onerous. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California heat wave may rival deadly July 2006 event, forecasters say
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski
item.description: High pressure will reach a strength that occurs only about once every 10 years, the National Weather Service said, fueling a heat wave that could rival the seven-day event in 2006 that researchers connected to hundreds of deaths.
item.content:encoded: High pressure will reach a strength that occurs only about once every 10 years, the National Weather Service said, fueling a heat wave that could rival the seven-day event in 2006 that researchers connected to hundreds of deaths.

media:content.media:description: The extended outlook calls for temperatures to continue to be above normal in California and the Southwest.

item.title: Some evacuation orders lifted as firefighters continue battle on Lake fire
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Officials lifted additional evacuation orders that had been put in place Friday evening for Antelope Valley residents. Previously declared evacuation orders were maintained, however, as the Lake fire continued to pose a threat.
item.content:encoded: Officials lifted additional evacuation orders that had been put in place Friday evening for Antelope Valley residents. Previously declared evacuation orders were maintained, however, as the Lake fire continued to pose a threat.

media:content.media:description: LAKE HUGHES, CA. August 12, 2020: A fast-moving brush fire blacked 400 acres in an hour this afternoon in Lake Hughes, and fire officials said it had the potential to burn 1,000 acres. The Lake Fire was reported at about 3:30 p.m. near North Lake Hughes Road and Pine Canyon Road in the Angeles National Forest, according to Marvin Lim of the Los Angeles County Fire Department, which was battling the blaze with Angeles National Forest crews. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles)

item.title: Los Angeles won't ticket for street sweeping violations until October at the earliest

item.description: The city delayed the return of street sweeping tickets by two months or more to encourage residents to stay home.

item.title: California begins rolling blackouts after first Stage 3 emergency since 2001
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: The body that runs the electric grid for most of California has declared a statewide Stage 3 emergency due to excessive heat driving up electricity use and straining the grid.
item.content:encoded: The body that runs the electric grid for most of California has declared a statewide Stage 3 emergency due to excessive heat driving up electricity use and straining the grid.

media:content.media:description: The manager of California's electric grid says expanding the agency's operations would save consumers $1.5 billion.

item.title: How to adapt special education to the remote-learning reality

media:content.media:description: Lamar Elementary School principal Erin Honeycutt sets up a "Zoom" class for first through fifth graders to learn art from Holly Triplett in Meridian, Miss., Tuesday, March 24, 2020. The COVID-19 and coronavirus has forced area schools to close and use technology for online teaching and learning. At this time Lamar is closed until April 13th and will then re-evaluate as to continue their closure. (Paula Merritt/The Meridian Star via AP)

A heat wave is expected to grip Southern California through the weekend, with inland temperatures reaching triple digits. (Luis Sinco/Los Aneles Time)

item.title: Jackie Lacey's husband claims state charges against him in gun case are improper
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: David Lacey, the husband of Los Angeles County's district attorney, seeks to have charges that he pointed a gun at protesters at his door dismissed.
item.content:encoded: David Lacey, the husband of Los Angeles County's district attorney, seeks to have charges that he pointed a gun at protesters at his door dismissed.

media:content.media:description: This video still image provided by Dahlia Ferlito shows Los Angeles County District Attorney Jackie Lacey's husband David Lacey pointing a gun at Black Lives Matter protesters outside their home in the Granada Hills section of Los Angeles on Monday, March 2, 2020. The first black woman to lead the largest local prosecutor's office in the U.S. apologized for her husband pointing the gun at Black Lives Matter demonstrators who came to their Los Angeles home before dawn Monday. (Dahlia Ferlito via AP)

item.title: Back to school in a pandemic: Resources and news for parents

As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

Doors opened at 6 a.m. for seniors and at-risk shoppers due to the Coronavirus. Most of the team arrives at 5 a.m. to stock the shelves with product, sanitize the location for staff and shoppers, and picker/shoppers begin to collect items for .com home delivery shoppers. Vendors arriving throughout the morning must read a checklist of warnings, sign in and they must wear face covering. Vons on Monday, April 27, 2020 in Torrance, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Photos: Christian faithful have been gathering, raising their hands skyward and, for some, stepping into the cool Pacific to be baptized.

media:content.media:description: Corona del Mar, California-July 31, 2020-Amber Strayhand (right) is baptized at Corona Del Mar State Park as a part of Saturate OC. The religious group Saturate OC is made up of over 60 churches from California and beyond, gather at Corona del Mar State Beach, CA, on August 7, 2020, to pray and do baptisms in the ocean. Almost no one in the group was wearing a mask despite the rising cases of coronavirus in California. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

The unparalleled disruption of California schools has had profound impacts on students in high-poverty communities. Diaz did not receive a computer to work from home until more than a month after the shutdown and struggled to find motivation to complete schoolwork without the in person interaction. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

The demonstrators are protesting police brutality and racial discrimination in Los Angeles, CA June 2, 2020. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In her native California, Kamala Harris VP pick brings excitement and doubts
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown, Marisa Gerber, Andrea Castillo, Susanne Rust
item.description: Kamala Harris, long influential in California political circles, is now on the ticket as vice president.
item.content:encoded: Kamala Harris, long influential in California political circles, is now on the ticket as vice president.

media:content.media:description: Democratic presidential candidate former Vice President Joe Biden, left, and Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif. shake hands after a Democratic presidential primary debate hosted at Texas Southern University in Houston.

item.title: 'I've now dipped into the pie.' Will COVID-19 change Americans' views of the social safety net?
item.dc:creator: Marisa Gerber
item.description: As more Americans benefit from federal aid during the pandemic, some believe the discourse about the role of government in U.S. life could shift.
item.content:encoded: As more Americans benefit from federal aid during the pandemic, some believe the discourse about the role of government in U.S. life could shift.

media:content.media:description: ENCINITAS, CA - AUGUST 04: Jim Brady, center, CEO of AToN, a rehab company that he started with his wife, Patricia Brady, left, more than a decade ago, and their daughter, Pat, chief operating officer, at the AToN Center, a luxury drug and alcohol addiction treatment center in Encinitas Tuesday, Aug. 4, 2020. As the coronavirus charted its deadly path across the country, Brady decided to temporarily stop accepting clients from some East Coast hot spots and drastically cut client capacity so patients didn't have to share bathrooms. Before long, he was losing a ton of money but he was determined not to layoff any employees. Instead, he applied for and got a PPP loan for about $800,000 from the federal government to cover payroll and a few other things. The experience of accepting government funds has prompted Brady to rethink some of his views on government aid - something he never expected to need. But now that he's watched the positive ripple effect of having received the loan - how it helped him, his family, his employees and their families - his more rigid views of government assistance have started to evolve. "I have a very different eye to that now. I've now dipped into the pie." (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. school board approves deal on remote learning; critics say it falls short on teaching
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: L.A. Board of Education approves agreement with union for structured online teaching. Critics say it needlessly shortens the traditional school day.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Board of Education approves agreement with union for structured online teaching. Critics say it needlessly shortens the traditional school day.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 07: Los Angeles Unified School District Superintendent Austin Beutner demonstrates the use of sanitizing tools while taking a tour of Burbank Middle School with Principal Christine Moore on Friday, Aug. 7, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As the academic school year looms, preparations have been under way to make campuses safe inside and out, even though the school year will start with distance-learning only because of the surging coronavirus pandemic. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: De León expected to take over seat of suspended L.A. Councilman Huizar in October
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: The council president has set out plans for a "caretaker" to manage Huizar's district until former state Senate Leader Kevin de León is appointed in October.
item.content:encoded: The council president has set out plans for a "caretaker" to manage Huizar's district until former state Senate Leader Kevin de León is appointed in October.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIAÑFEB. 5, 2020ÑFormer State Sen. Kevin de Leon takes part in a pre-election forum for the LA City Council 14th District in Little Tokyo on Feb. 5, 2020. The candidates for Los Angeles City Council in the 14th District take part in a candidate forum in Little Tokyo on Feb. 5, 2020. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Heat watch issued for much of Southern California this weekend
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: The National Weather Service has issued an excessive heat watch for much of Southern California this weekend, forecasting that temperatures will near record highs throughout the region.
item.content:encoded: The National Weather Service has issued an excessive heat watch for much of Southern California this weekend, forecasting that temperatures will near record highs throughout the region.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 11: Pedestrians are required to wear a mask and practice social distancing when visiting Main Street in downtown Ventura which has been closed to vehicle traffic to allow restaurants and businesses to accommodate for outdoor dining and shopping in the era of the Covid-19 Coronavirus pandemic on August 11, 2020. Los Angeles on Tuesday, Aug. 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Mayor Garcetti's top homelessness advisor to resign
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Mayor Eric Garcetti's top advisor on homelessness, Deputy Mayor Christina Miller, has told colleagues that she plans to resign at the end of the month.
item.content:encoded: Mayor Eric Garcetti's top advisor on homelessness, Deputy Mayor Christina Miller, has told colleagues that she plans to resign at the end of the month.

media:content.media:description: Deputy Mayor of Los Angeles, Christina Miller. She was Mayor Garcetti's top adviser on homelessness.

item.title: Family of dead woman allegedly groped by LAPD officer files lawsuit
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: While on duty, an LAPD officer allegedly fondled the breasts of a woman he had found dead. Her family is suing the officer and the city of L.A.
item.content:encoded: While on duty, an LAPD officer allegedly fondled the breasts of a woman he had found dead. Her family is suing the officer and the city of L.A.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 11: Janet Baggett, mother of the late Elizabeth Baggett, wipes her eyes as Attorney Gloria Allred speaks at a press conference on Tuesday, Aug. 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Allred's film, Allred, Maroko & Goldberg, filed the lawsuit on behalf of the estate of Elizabeth Baggett, whose dead body was allegedly fondled by an on-duty Los Angeles Police Department officer. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Los Angeles County tops 5,000 coronavirus deaths
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna, Phil Willon, Laura J. Nelson
item.description: The county's infection rate is substantially lower than Central Valley counties where case rates are surging
item.content:encoded: The county's infection rate is substantially lower than Central Valley counties where case rates are surging

media:content.media:description: COLTON, CA - APRIL 09: Alejandra Ortiz, left, sits in her car as a nurse administers a coronavirus COVID-19 test at Arrowhead Regional Medical Center durning public testing drive-through in Colton, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: With Kamala Harris as Biden's VP pick, Newsom has a chance to appoint history-making senator
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: The appointment promises to be one of the most consequential of his political career, both in California and in regard to any ambitions he may have for White House.
item.content:encoded: The appointment promises to be one of the most consequential of his political career, both in California and in regard to any ambitions he may have for White House.

media:content.media:description: Sen. Kamala Harris, left, endorses California Lt. Gov. Gavin Newsom for the 2018 California Governor's race at the Ronald Tutor Campus Center at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles, Friday, Feb. 16, 2018. (AP Photo/Damian Dovarganes)

item.title: How has the COVID-19 pandemic affected your commute?
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: The pandemic has forced thousands of workplaces to quickly adjust to remote work. Will your employer keep some of those changes in place permanently?
item.content:encoded: The pandemic has forced thousands of workplaces to quickly adjust to remote work. Will your employer keep some of those changes in place permanently?

media:content.media:description: ONTARIO, CA - MAY 08: The morning commute on the southbound 15 Freeway in Ontario was slightly busier May 8 than in prior weeks. Freeway I-15 on Friday, May 8, 2020 in Ontario, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Pew poll finds most Latinos haven't heard of 'Latinx.' Only 3% use the term
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hernandez
item.description: Some three out of four Latinos in the U.S. haven't heard of the term 'Latinx,' but its use may grow.
item.content:encoded: Some three out of four Latinos in the U.S. haven't heard of the term 'Latinx,' but its use may grow.

media:content.media:description: A woman waves a U.S. flag as marchers make their way down Broadway in downtown Los Angeles during a 2011 May Day event calling for immigration reform.

item.title: Cow chase leads to helicopter rescue in Solano County
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Two people encountered a bad-tempered bovine at Lynch Canyon Open Space Park and were injured while fleeing. A helicopter rescue followed the cow chase.
item.content:encoded: Two people encountered a bad-tempered bovine at Lynch Canyon Open Space Park and were injured while fleeing. A helicopter rescue followed the cow chase.

media:content.media:description: An elderly couple was injured and had to be airlifted out of a Solano County park Sunday after falling while being chased by a cow, authorities said.
media:content.media:credit: California Highway Patrol, Golden Gate Division Air Operations

item.title: Child is first person in Orange County to contract West Nile virus this year
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Ten other human West Nile virus cases have been confirmed statewide in 2020, eight in Stanislaus County, and the others in L.A. and Madera counties.
item.content:encoded: Ten other human West Nile virus cases have been confirmed statewide in 2020, eight in Stanislaus County, and the others in L.A. and Madera counties.

media:content.media:description: How did this mosquito pick this particular victim? The victim's genes likely played a big role, a new study suggests.
